verses.text: How beautiful are your feet in sandals, noble daughter! The curves of your thighs are like ornaments, crafted by the hands of an artist.
verses.comment: This verse uses poetic imagery to praise the beloved’s beauty, evoking the way the Church is adorned as Christ’s bride (see Ephesians 5:27). The use of 'noble daughter' is a literal rendering, emphasizing dignity.

verses.text: Your navel is a rounded bowl that never lacks mixed wine. Your waist is a heap of wheat, encircled with lilies.
verses.comment: Wine and wheat are here images of blessing and abundance, prefiguring sacred symbols later seen in the New Testament.

verses.text: Your two breasts are like two fawns, twins of a gazelle.
verses.comment: Repeated from Song 4:5, this metaphor stresses innocence and gentleness. Traditionally interpreted as representing the nurturing teachings of faith and love.

verses.text: Your neck is like an ivory tower. Your eyes are like the pools in Heshbon, by the gate of Bath-rabbim. Your nose is like a tower of Lebanon, facing Damascus.
verses.comment: The imagery of towers and pools connotes majesty, purity, and vigilance, reminiscent of the spiritual strength found in the communion of believers.

verses.text: Your head crowns you like Carmel, and the flowing locks of your hair are like purple; a king is held captive by your tresses.
verses.comment: Carmel represents fruitfulness, and the mention of the king hints at the royal relationship between Christ and His people (see Psalm 45:11).

verses.text: How beautiful and pleasant you are, O loved one, with your delights!
verses.comment: Echoes previous passages on the beloved’s beauty (Song 4:10). Love here signifies not mere human affection but the profound union between Christ and the faithful.

verses.text: Your stature is like a palm tree, and your breasts are like its clusters of fruit.
verses.comment: Palm trees in Scripture symbolize enduring righteousness and flourish (Psalm 92:12); the fruitfulness points toward spiritual abundance.

verses.text: I said, 'I will climb the palm tree, I will take hold of its fruit.' May your breasts be like clusters of the vine, the scent of your breath like apples,
verses.comment: The desire to partake in the beloved’s fruit points to longing for spiritual communion. The fragrance here recalls the pleasing aroma of offering (Genesis 8:21).

verses.text: and your mouth like the best wine.' She responds: 'May the wine go straight to my beloved, flowing smoothly to those who sleep, touching the lips of those who slumber.'
verses.comment: Wine represents joy and deep fellowship, later fulfilled in the Last Supper’s cup—a symbol of union and covenant.

verses.text: I am my beloved’s, and his desire is for me.
verses.comment: Echoing Song 6:3, this expresses total belonging and mutual love—a reflection of the soul’s union with Christ and His sacrificial desire for His people.

verses.text: Come, my beloved, let us go out into the countryside; let us spend the night among the villages.
verses.comment: This invitation to journey together evokes missionary callings and spiritual pilgrimage with Christ, similar to invitations found in Song 2:10 and Song 4:8.

verses.text: Let us rise early and go to the vineyards, to see if the vine has budded, if the blossoms have opened and the pomegranates are in bloom. There I will give you my love.
verses.comment: The vineyard represents fruitfulness and spiritual growth; early rising recalls devoted seeking (see Song 6:11).

verses.text: The mandrakes send forth fragrance, and at our doors are all choice fruits, new and old, which I have stored up for you, my beloved.
verses.comment: Mandrakes symbolize love and fruitfulness (Genesis 30:14), the stored fruits hint at tradition and continuity in spiritual gifts—old and new, kept for the beloved.
